p.s: The first quatrain the lyrical I uses the metaphor waves make towards the pebbled stone (l. 1) to emphasis how fast his aging prozessprocess is and that his time will soon end.
With the simile of the fast passing and aggresive waves and the passing time the lyrical I stresses on the passing time (l. 1-2).
The lyrical I also says that even with the changing place with that which goes before (l. 3) he can not runaway from the soon coming hardships of death (vgl. l. 4).
In conclusion the frist quatrain is about the short time the lyrical I has left.
The second quatrain the lyrical I talks about Christ and how he once was the main of the light (l. 5).
With this symbolesymbol he tries to show how Jesus was once the center and as time passes healso lost his life.
the lyrical I emphasises that even people who where important died and that concludes that of course he also had to die.

The oxymoron crawls to maturity (l. 6) stresses on the fact, that the time till being a adult, passes slowelyslowly but once the death crooked eclipses(l. 7) comes the gift of being extraordinary or important won't help you from dying.
He expresses this with the line And time that gave doth now his gift confound (l. 8).
The third quatrain deals with youth.
The antitheseantithesis time doth tansfix the flourish set on youth (l. 9) expresses the even though time brings the lyrical I faster to the end, it also hold on his youth.
It also searched for the similarities in the beautyiesbeauty's brow (l. 10), but time also slowelyslowly ledsled to the withering or forgiveness of the unique parts of a person.
He emphasizes it with the metaphermetaphor Feeds on the [...] of nature's truth, [...] (l. 11).

In the last lines of the quatrain he uses the metaphermetaphor woods or forest and the trees as the person's the lyrical I'sIs lifetime and that the time slowelyslowly mow[s] (l. 12) his lifetimes till nothing is left and he dies.
The quatrain underlines his opinion, that eventhougheven though he dies by the cruel hand of time (l. 14).
He hopes that the young man still remembers him, so he can - even in the end of his time - show the young man his worth (l. 13-14) and the love towards him.
Through his way of using the metaphors I can feel his fear of death, but also that he accepts it.
He talks about his youth happily and still sees the death as evil crooked eclipses but hopes for the best.
